===Launch systems===
===Launch systems===
  +
The ''Nimitz''-class aircraft carriers use steam-powered catapults to launch aircraft. [[Aircraft catapult|Steam catapults]] were developed in the 1950s and have been exceptionally reliable. For over fifty years at least one of the four catapults has been able to launch an aircraft 99.5% of the time.<ref>Schank, John. ''Modernizing the U.S. Aircraft Carrier Fleet'', p. 80.</ref> However, there are a number of drawbacks. âThe foremost deficiency is that the catapult operates without [[Control Theory|feedback control]]. With no feedback, there often occurs large [[Transient (oscillation)|transients]] in tow force that can damage or reduce the life of the airframe.â<ref>Doyle, Michael, Douglas Samuel, Thomas Conway, and Robert Klimowski. "Electromagnetic Aircraft Launch System - EMALS." Naval Air Engineering Station Lakehurst. 1 March. p. 1.</ref> The steam system is massive, inefficient (4â6%),<ref>Doyle, Michael, "Electromagnetic Aircraft Launch System - EMALS." p. 1.</ref> and hard to control.
Control problems with the system results in minimum and maximum weight limits. The minimum weight limit is above the weight of all [[Unmanned aerial vehicle|UAV]]s. An inability to launch the latest additions to the [[Modern US Navy carrier air operations|Naval Air Forces]] is a restriction on operations that cannot continue into the next generation of aircraft carriers. The [[Electromagnetic Aircraft Launch System|Electromagnetic Aircraft Launch System (EMALS)]] provides solutions to all these problems. An electromagnetic system is more efficient, smaller, lighter, more powerful, and easier to control. Increased control means that [[Electromagnetic Aircraft Launch System|EMALS]] will be able to launch both heavier and lighter aircraft than the steam catapult. Also, the use of a controlled force will reduce the stress on airframes, resulting in less maintenance and a longer lifetime for the airframe. Unfortunately the power limitations for the ''Nimitz'' class make the installation of the recently developed EMALS impossible.
